 You mention quarks as an example where we know that we do not know something (or other) is the case. It's true, we do not have direct knowledge about the "intrinsic nature" of a quark - which does not exist in isolation anyway. But what we do claim to know here turns out to be far from definitive. The quark hypothesis has been adopted because it is more economical (parsimonious) in explaining the nature of elementary particles than developing a theory that could make sense of the previous ocean of (uncategorized) necessary elementary particles. On this basis, the quark hypothesis is a fundamental in the current scientific model of the sub-atomic world. As I think you would agree, this model is provisional and tentative: it would be modified or even discarded in the light of further empirical evidence or if an internal contradiction was discovered. Does all this add up to knowledge about quarks or merely a belief in them ?

Given two choices, the known bad and the unknown, which do you choose?
 
 Always choose the unknown. 
 

 
 I think this faulty premise leads to to a faulty conclusion. The use of the word "always" renders the premise erroneous. To a first order, given no aversion to risk, one should choose the unknown if is has a higher expectation (value, using whatever metric you find appropriate) than the known bad. If not having enough cash on hand to purchase an island paradise is a known bad, one could conclude that he should wager his house and all other assets on the state lottery (the unknown). 
 
 Poker players that adopted that strategy (i.e., always chose the unknown) would never under any circumstances fold a hand. The known bad would be to lose the existing pot, while the unknown would be that your opponent has even a worse hand or can be bluffed out of a better one.
